results.title: The Man in the middle
results.creator_credit: British Productivity Council, Millbank Films and Fred Moore
results.brief_description: The supervisor is sandwiched in the no-man’s land between “them and us”. Intended for training supervisors, the film illustrates that they are required to maintain full production and look after the health, safety and welfare of the employees.

results.title: The Man in the irony mask
results.creator_credit: Paul Andrew, Kath Shelper and Scarlett Pictures
results.brief_description: This documentary portrays the life and death of performance artist and AIDS activist, Brenton Heath-Kerr. Through his repertoire of performances, costumes and photographs, Heath-Kerr challenged perceptions, dominant sterotypes and myths which he thought underpinned the gay communities and notions of gay identity. An emigre of drag and a gender misfit, Heath-Kerr understood that often holding a mask up to society had more political impact than holding up a mirror. (Source: Trove)

results.title: The Man in the glass booth
results.creator_credit: Ely Landau, Arthur Hiller, Ely Landau Organization and Cinevision Ltee
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Searing adaptation made for the American Film Theatre collection, of the Robert Shaw play, about a wealthy Jewish man living in Manhattan who is beset by demons and paranoia. A survivor of the Holocaust, Arthur Goldman is one day kidnapped and shipped to Israel where he is tried for war crimes. But is this character the victim or the perpetrator? With its claustrophobic and minimalist setting, Arthur Hiller teases out the themes of guilt, paranoia, conspiracy theories and martyrdom. Maximillian Schell was nominated for an Academy Award for his portrayal of Goldman, but the adaptation itself was controversial, with Shaw removing his name from the credits, due to dissatisfaction with Edward Anhalt’s screenplay.

results.title: The Man in the blue helmet
results.creator_credit: Alistair Cooke, United Nations Films and Frank Jacoby
results.brief_description: Tells of current events in the United Nations and the work of the UN police force. The story of the United Nations soldier, how he came into being, how he works and lives in stange lands, often far from his own country. The problem of maintaining the peace in the Congo and in the Middle East is shown.

results.title: The Man in the blue and white Holden
results.creator_credit: Jane Karslake, Film Victoria and Peter Luby
results.brief_description: A comedy with suspense about childhood fears set in the late sixties. Following the disappearance of the Beaumont children, Colin is warned about a malevolent stranger who has abducted children. Colin believes he is being shadowed by the man in a blue and white Holden. The film recalls the childhood fears drummed into children by teachers and parents, of strangers in cars. Cast includes Jeffrey Walker, Fiona Corke and Chris McLean.

results.title: The Man in grey
results.creator_credit: Edward Black, Gainsborough Pictures and Leslie Arliss
results.brief_description: First of the very popular British costume melodramas produced by Gainsborough and often thought of as the best in the collection, “The Man in grey” is a tale of intrigue that twists and turns its way to a dramatic conclusion. The story begins at an antique auction in London during WWII and then proceeds to flashback to 19th century regal England to the aristocratic world of Clarissa Richmond (Phyllis Calvert) and her loveless marriage to the rather indifferent Lord Rohan (James Mason) - the “man in grey”, whose sole intent is in fathering an heir. Clarissa soon finds herself distracted by the attentions of the handsome Rokeby (Stewart Granger) introduced to her by her old schoolfriend, Hester (Margaret Lockwood) who in turn falls for Lord Rohan. Deceit, love and betrayal weave their way into this web of treachery where circumstances and fate can only lead to a tragic conclusion. Magnificent performances by all four stars. Based on the novel by Lady Eleanor Smith, adapted by Doreen Montgomery with screenplay by Margaret Kennedy and Leslie Arliss.

results.title: The Man hunters
results.brief_description: An introduction to the study of fossil homo sapiens, this film provides a starting point for more detailed discussions. Presents a time line upon which only a small part represents recorded history, the rest is pre-history. The film also discusses a 100 year search by scientists for the earliest evidence of human existence. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: The Man from Tocumwal
results.creator_credit: John Sparkes, Ken Dyer and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
A study of Fred James, managing director of the textile firm Cleckheaton, and new owner of the famous Falkiner Merino Stud at Congaro, N.S.W. James explains his interest in the wool industry, criticises the Australian Wool Board and discusses wool’s marketing and promotional problems. Also shows his modern textile mill at Shepparton, Victoria.

results.title: The Man from Snowy River II
results.brief_description: Jim Craig has been away on the plains droving and gathering a large mob of horses to breed in his high country. Now he has returned to claim his heritage and the woman he loves. “The Man From Snowy River II” continues the legend and brings to life a man whose simple strength will endure forever.
